citations.narrative:
USDA Officials identified several enclosures in need of repair.
• The licensee stated during the inspection that an enclosure housing New Guinea Singing Dogs experienced excess
runoff during a heavy rainstorm. This water flooded an area that a female had dug out and was denning her puppies. Two
of the puppies drowned according to the licensee.
• In the enclosure housing three domestic pigs and four domestic goats, there are loose wires from a damaged section of
fence. While the inspectors were viewing the enclosure, a pig hooked a tusk on one of the wires. Facility personal
immediately freed the animal and it was unharmed.
•In an enclosure housing four African lions, a support post holding up a resting platform has been reduced to
approximately half of its original thickness due to animal wear.
•One metal feeding bowl in the enclosure with two Syrian brown bears and one tiger has a significant hole in the side of
the bowl, creating sharp and jagged edges.
Housing facilities shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to
contain the animals. Housing for the species must be maintained to prevent injury or death to the animals possessed by
the licensee.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
KATIE PRICE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
USDA Officials identified several enclosures in need of repair.  
• The licensee stated during the inspection that an enclosure housing New Guinea Singing Dogs experienced excess 
runoff during a heavy rainstorm. This water flooded an area that a female had dug out and was denning her puppies. Two 
of the puppies drowned according to the licensee.  
• In the enclosure housing three domestic pigs and four domestic goats, there are loose wires from a damaged section of 
fence. While the inspectors were viewing the enclosure, a pig hooked a tusk on one of the wires. Facility personal 
immediately freed the animal and it was unharmed.  
•In an enclosure housing four African lions, a support post holding up a resting platform has been reduced to 
approximately half of its original thickness due to animal wear. 
•One metal feeding bowl in the enclosure with two Syrian brown bears and one tiger has a significant hole in the side of 
the bowl, creating sharp and jagged edges. 
 
Housing facilities shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to 
contain the animals. Housing for the species must be maintained to prevent injury or death to the animals possessed by 
the licensee. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KATIE PRICE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
